awd_titl_txt: Rethinking Social Change in Comparative Perspective
awd_abstract_narration:
In recent years, across multiple democratic nations around the world, a diverse array of citizens have come together in cities to give common expression to contemporary anxieties. The focus of their attention varies, but has, at different places and times, included immigration and the influx of refugees; the sustainability of public welfare programs; what are perceived as declining life chances; and a variety of forms of socio-economic differentiations. For social scientists, multiple questions have arisen around these developments. Is there a common thread and if so, do they represent new forms of social assortment? Or are they instead, ephemeral responses to temporary social stresses, with no long-term consequences? The research supported by this award addresses these questions. The research is important for several reasons. The first is that social scientists rarely have the opportunity to study major social shifts as they are taking place. But equally important, policy makers and others concerned for the general welfare need to better understand the significance of what has happened around them.

To pursue these issues and the challenges they might represent to democracy, anthropologist Dr. Ida Susser, of the City University of New York, will explore the social and temporal dynamics that shape the "Squares" movement, known in the United States as "Occupy," in two cities of the European Union, Paris and Barcelona. The research will provide an account of these contemporary efforts at social transformation, analyzing how conceptions of time might shape political action, the social composition of activist groups, and the material experiences of occupation. Data will be collected through participant observation, open-ended interviews, digital ethnography, and the analysis of primary and secondary materials. Together with colleagues in Spain and France, the esearcher will follow selected community organizations and new political parties formed in the aftermath of Squares actions. They will assess long-term impacts including effects on national discourse and democratic poiltics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
This research provides an account of contemporary efforts at  social change through street protest and community organizing, analyzing the ways different historical moments shape political action, the social composition of activist groups, and the changing experiences of occupations and ongoing street demonstrations. Initially, the research explored the social and temporal dynamics that shaped the Squares movement, known in the U.S. as Occupy, in two cities of the European Union, Paris and Barcelona. Later the project focused on the ways in which these movements have informed or contributed to subsequent political contestations.

Specific objectives

To understand how or whether social change is promoted by social movements, neighborhood organizing, or other kinds of community activities.

Methods

Based on historical accounts, participant observation, open-ended interviews and the collection of primary and secondary materials, the project asked whether the Squares produced broader shifts in political thought and action. The research followed selected grassroots organizations and new political parties which formed in the aftermath of the Squares to assess the impact of the events on national discourse and to determine how such events may have precipitated various forms of social change.

The project  observed and interviewed participants in activities initiated during the protest movements in Paris and Barcelona. The  activities described and analyzed included the organizing of a bicycle delivery cooperative, food collectives and new political parties. The research also followed  local housing movements that were helping home owners and renters to adjust their mortgages and rents and setting up new cooperative housing, as well as further street protests as they emerged. To provide a context for the grassroots organizing and collective activities the project also conducted ethnographic research in a diverse working class suburb of Paris.

Significant findings

The research suggested that grass roots organizing promotes more inclusive  perspectives on problems such as housing, food insecurity and perceptions of refugees and asylum seekers than might otherwise be found in diverse neighborhoods.

The project developed ideas of thresholding and commoning as useful ways to conceptualize informal movements of social change. Thresholding as developed in this research conotes groups working across identities and other boundaries without actual convergence in all goals and activities. Commoning, as it has been used in recent years, describes the ways in which people occupy squares, buildings and other spaces together over time in protest against a wide variety of issues.

Outcomes

A number of presentations and articles  have resulted from the research and  one monograph has been accepted for publication, open access. A co-edited volume is also in preparation.

Professional Development

The PI worked with masters and doctoral students in Barcelona, Paris and New York City in supervising or helping them to develop their own research and publications around issues related to neighborhood movements and political change.  The PI gave seminars, presentations and workshops in Paris, Barcelona, Zaragossa (Spain), New York City, and elsewhere for students, researchers and grassroots activists. In addition, the PI was  invited to present the research at different universities in Paris and New York City and to participate in  month-long workshops at EHESS (Ecole des Hautes Etudes en Sciences Sociales) as well as at annual departmental seminars in anthropology at EHESS and in several other ongoing seminars.


Last Modified: 10/16/2024
Modified by: Ida Susser
